channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Flaw in Biden’s Pro-Labor Record: Uber Drivers Are Still Waiting for Help
item.description: The administration’s plans to strengthen their labor protections have been slowed by Congress, the courts and a lobbying blitz.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning and Michael D. Shear
item.category: American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nicole Moore, a Lyft driver and labor activist, hoped the Biden administration would tackle gig worker issues more aggressively.

item.title: Strikes Sweep the U.K. as Workers Demand Better Pay
item.description: Backed by unions and tired of years of low wage growth, workers are making bold pay demands to cope with the rising cost of living. Some say this is just the beginning.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Max Miechowski for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers on strike at the Port of Felixstowe last month.

item.title: Biden Warns That American Values Are Under Assault by Trump-Led Extremism
item.description: In a prime-time speech in Philadelphia, President Biden cast the midterm elections as a choice between his agenda and the extremism of “MAGA Republicans.”
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Oliver Contreras for The New York Times

item.title: A Rematch of Biden v. Trump, Two Years Early
item.description: Dispensing with his unity message, President Biden reached into the 2020 file cabinet and vowed to win “a battle for the soul of this nation,” the cornerstone of his successful election.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: In a speech in Philadelphia, President Biden warned against “a blind loyalty to a single leader and a willingness to engage in political violence.”

item.title: Takeaways From Biden’s Speech in Philadelphia
item.description: The president tacitly acknowledged that his predecessor still looms over the politics of the moment.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman
item.media:description: President Biden alternated in his speech between pointing to the threats America faces from extremism and his administration’s success in pushing through key elements of his agenda.

item.title: Trump’s Tastes in Intelligence Were About His Power and Leverage
item.description: President Donald J. Trump’s interests during classified briefings have a new resonance amid the Justice Department’s criminal investigation into his handling of sensitive documents.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Michael C. Bender and Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Donald J. Trump in the Oval Office. He would sometimes ask to keep material from classified briefings.

item.title: Judge Keeps Door Open to Special Master in Trump Documents Inquiry
item.description: The federal judge in Florida also indicated that she would unseal a more detailed inventory of the materials seized in the search of the former president’s Mar-a-Lago home.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei, Alan Feuer and Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The appointment of an independent arbiter is unlikely to derail the Justice Department’s inquiry into whether former President Donald J. Trump illegally held onto national security papers at his beachfront property.

item.title: Trying to Sell Your Old Peloton Bike? So Is Peloton.
item.description: As its business slumps, Peloton is trying something new: selling its bikes to “value-minded” customers. It faces stiff competition.
item.dc:creator: Lora Kelley

item.title: ‘Condemned to Lead’ Europe, German Chancellor Struggles for Impact
item.description: Facing its worst crisis since World War II, Europe is looking for leadership. Olaf Scholz is trying to take up the role, but faces a tepid response.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz in Berlin this week.

item.title: Venus and Serena William Lose First Round Doubles Match at US Open
item.description: Serena and Venus Williams lost the first set even after having a set point. They eventually were defeated, 7-6 (5), 6-4, by Lucie Hradecka and Linda Noskova of the Czech Republic.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:description: Venus, left, and Serena Williams’s doubles stint lasted only one match.

item.title: Serena Williams Prepared a Little Differently for This U.S. Open
item.description: Analytics, scouting first-time opponents, additional coaching input, new footwork drills and treating doubles like practice — so far it’s adding up to winning.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Serena Williams is into the third round of singles in her final U.S. Open.

item.title: Sex Ed Emerges as Core Issue for N.J. Republicans as Midterms Approach
item.description: New education standards that touch on gender identity have caused a stir in New Jersey. Some Republicans are trying to keep the conversation alive.
item.dc:creator: Tracey Tully
item.media:description: New Jersey schools are set to implement new sex-education standards this school year.

item.title: A Flight Attendant Answers Your Burning Travel and Etiquette Questions
item.description: Where is the best seat if you’re airsick prone? Why don’t flight crews eat the same meals? And the age-old question: Can middle-seat passengers really claim both armrests?
item.dc:creator: Kristie Koerbel
item.media:description: “We all hate the middle,” writes Kristie Koerbel, a flight attendant for 20 years, about the center seat.

item.title: If an Alternative Candidate Is Needed in 2024, These Folks Will Be Ready
item.description: If the two parties go off to the edges there’ll be a ticket running up the center.
item.dc:creator: David Brooks
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times

item.title: The Day Gorbachev Made D.C. Stand Still
item.description: The Adventures of Mikhail Sergeyevich: An astrologer, an anaconda and a backward motorcade.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.media:description: Mikhail Gorbachev in Washington, D.C., after he ordered his motorcade to stop on the way to the White House in 1987.

item.title: Salman Rushdie and What It Means to Support Free Speech
item.description: I felt the power of the rush of readers who ran to the stage when Salman Rushdie was attacked.
item.dc:creator: Henry Reese
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: What Brittney Griner’s Income Says About Women’s Basketball
item.description: As Brittney Griner’s attorneys appeal her conviction in a Russian court, questions remain about why Ms. Griner and other W.N.B.A. stars play abroad to supplement their incomes.
item.dc:creator: Mary Pilon

item.title: Amazon Can’t Fix America’s Health Care Crisis
item.description: There is no technological miracle that will fix decades of bad policy.
item.dc:creator: Libby Watson

item.title: How to Have Fun Again
item.description: An illustrated guide to letting loose.
item.dc:creator: Wendy MacNaughton

item.title: A Farewell to Readers
item.description: Binary thinking in politics, race and inequality has distracted us from processing everything else that takes place in the country.
item.dc:creator: Jay Caspian Kang

item.title: The Serena Effect
item.description: An improbable run at what may be her final U.S. Open.
item.dc:creator: Kurt Streeter
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Serena Williams defeated Anett Kontaveit and will face Ajla Tomljanovic in the third round of the U.S. Open on Friday.

item.title: Vancouver’s Unconventional Approach to Its Fentanyl Crisis
item.description: The Canadian city has taken the concept of harm reduction to a new level in an effort to address the growing toxicity of street drugs.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff, Sydney Harper, Jessica Cheung, Asthaa Chaturvedi, M.J. Davis Lin, Liz O. Baylen, Ben Calhoun, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Chelsea Daniel and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Jackie Dives for The New York Times
item.media:description: Injection supplies at a clinic in Vancouver. The fentanyl dispensary at the clinic is legal, and Canada’s public health system finances it.

item.title: Good Things to Make With Summer Corn
item.description: Raw, stir-fried, grilled and puréed — there’s a corn recipe for every mood.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao
item.media:credit: Andrew Scrivani for The New York Times

item.title: Why We Get Motion Sick, and How to Stop It
item.description: Experts say prevention is the best cure.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Illustration by Guillem Casasus; Photograph by Getty Images

item.title: Argentina’s Vice President Unharmed After Assassination Attempt
item.description: A man tried to fire a gun inches from the head of Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, the country’s most prominent leader, but it did not go off.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Natalie Alcoba
item.media:description: Police officers arrested a man who pointed a firearm at Vice President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner outside her home in Buenos Aires on Thursday.

item.title: Chile Could Transform Indigenous Rights in Watershed Vote
item.description: The proposed constitution would enshrine some of the world’s most extensive Indigenous rights. But those reforms have become the focal point of the campaign to reject the new text.
item.dc:creator: Ana Lankes
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dancing the traditional Mapuche “purrun” during a rally last week in support of the new constitution in Santiago, Chile.

item.title: With the PGA Tour Season Over, LIV Golf Looks to Strengthen Its Foothold
item.description: Cameron Smith, the No. 2 player in the world, is among six veteran players who will make their debuts for the breakaway series at an event outside Boston this weekend.
item.dc:creator: Bill Pennington
item.media:description: Cameron Smith joined LIV Golf after winning the British Open earlier this year.

item.title: What Urban Planners Can Learn From This Idealistic Coffee Shop
item.description: Can a pay-what-you-want cafe exist in a gentrified Gowanus?
item.dc:creator: Ginia Bellafante
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Katie Bishop is the owner of Principles GI Coffee House, which was inspired by the egalitarian, antiwar coffeehouses that sprung up around military bases during the Vietnam War.

item.title: How Love Languages Became a Cultural Phenomenon
item.description: The author of the seminal book on love languages is surprised that the concept has become a cultural phenomenon. But he still wants couples to heed his advice.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Luis Mazón
item.media:description: Karolyn and Gary Chapman at their wedding reception in August 1961. The couple, who have been married for over 60 years, said they had a rocky start.

item.title: My Marriage Has a Third Wheel: Our Child
item.description: An only child can make the relationship between Mom and Dad uniquely complicated.
item.dc:creator: Jancee Dunn

item.title: How to Spot a Love Addict
item.description: Experts question whether we can describe a toxic relationship the way we talk about gambling or alcohol. But some have found that framework to be a helpful step in the road to freedom.
item.dc:creator: Kaila Yu

item.title: Dealing With Interfering Grandparents
item.description: How to navigate a challenging relationship.
item.dc:creator: Carla Bruce-Eddings

item.title: Sometimes I Hate My Husband’s Peloton
item.description: Yes, exercise is hugely beneficial. But can too much of a good thing cause tension in your relationship?
item.dc:creator: Holly Burns

item.title: At Shakespeare’s Globe, a Nonbinary Joan of Arc Causes a Stir
item.description: Even before the production debuted, it had inflamed a rancorous debate about sex and gender that plays out almost daily in Britain.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
